Introduction

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability.

Pathophysiology



MG is caused by an autoantibody-mediated, T cellâ€“dependent attack on the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) of the neuromuscular junction (

figure 1
).  Blockade of the active site of AChRs prevents acetylcholine from binding and also triggers endocytosis of AChRs (receptor internalization), as well as complement-mediated membrane damage.  Over time, these changes result in reduced numbers of AChRs.  The decrease in available cation channels reduces the end plate potential following acetylcholine release (
figure 2
).  Because the threshold potential is not reached, the muscle cells do not depolarize as frequently, leading to defective neuromuscular transmission.



The thymus is involved in the differentiation of T cells and seems to be the site of autoimmunization in MG, perhaps by reacting to muscle-like cells in the thymus that express AChR antibodies.  This may be why most patients with MG are found to have some form of thymic disease (thymic hyperplasia, thymoma).

Epidemiology and risk factors



MG is a rare disorder that can occur at any age.  Most commonly, it occurs in 2 populations:  women age 20-30 and men age 60-80.  Thymic hyperplasia or thymoma is present in a significant proportion of MG cases.

Clinical presentation



MG is characterized clinically by weakness that is:



  • Fluctuating throughout the day
  • Fatigable (eg, worse after repetitive motions or at the end of the day)
  • Usually located in ocular, extremity, or bulbar muscles


Depending on which muscle groups are affected, clusters of symptoms can present in various ways:



  • Ocular symptoms:  are the most common and occur in about 50% of patients.  Patients usually report diplopia (eg, double vision) and ptosis (eg, drooping eyelid).  Any extraocular muscle can be impacted.  These symptoms tend to be worse after prolonged visual fixation, such as reading or driving.
  • Bulbar symptoms:  occur in approximately 16% of patients.  Patients can have slurred speech, changes in voice (eg, hypernasality due to palate weakness), trouble with chewing, and/or facial weakness.  If facial muscles are involved, patients may report decreased ability to smile or may have a "myasthenic sneer" in which the outer corners of the mouth do not move when attempting to smile.  Patients with bulbar symptoms are more likely to progress to respiratory failure related to MG.
  • Extremity weakness:  occurs in about 20% of patients, usually with ocular or bulbar symptoms.  MG classically impacts proximal more than distal extremities, which can present as difficulty rising from a seated position or lifting the arms over the head (eg, combing hair).  The arms are often affected more than the legs.  Patients can also have exercise intolerance characterized by weakness in the absence of dyspnea or tiredness.  Neck muscles also may be involved, causing some drooping of the head toward the end of the day.


Examination of patients can initially show normal strength, but additional clinical testing often provides clues.  Commonly used examination maneuvers include the following:



  • Sustained upward gaze (eg, having the patient look up for 60 seconds) to elicit ptosis.
  • Asking a patient to count out loud as high as they can in one breath.
  • Demonstrating repetitive shoulder abduction or hip flexion to elicit proximal muscle weakness.
  • Placing a cool pack on the eyelids to see if ptosis improves (eg, ice pack test).  This likely helps ptosis because acetylcholinesterase activity decreases at lower temperatures.


Because MG occurs at the level of the neuromuscular junction, upper and lower motor neuron signs (eg, hyperreflexia, fasciculations) are typically absent.  Sensation, muscle bulk/tone, reflexes, and autonomic function are typically normal.

Diagnosis



If a patient has a clinical presentation concerning for MG (

figure 3
), the diagnosis can be confirmed by serologic tests that detect serum autoantibodies against AChRs.  These can be detected in the majority of patients with MG and are very specific.  A small percentage have antibodies directed at muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) or low-density lipoprotein receptorâ€“related protein (LRP4), which can be tested for if AChR antibodies are negative.



Electrodiagnostic testing with electromyography and nerve conduction studies with repetitive nerve stimulation can be used when antibody testing is negative.  It shows a characteristic decreasing force of muscle contraction with repetitive nerve stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.



All patients with confirmed MG should undergo CT or MRI of the mediastinum to assess for thymoma or thymic hyperplasia, which may be associated with MG.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of MG includes:



  • Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS):  can have proximal muscle weakness (often in the legs > arms).  However, weakness usually improves (rather than worsens) with activity.  LEMS is caused by antibodies targeting presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels and is typically associated with small cell lung cancer.
  • Botulism:  can present with ocular and bulbar symptoms (eg, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia) similar to those of MG; however, patients typically present with very rapid progression of symptoms without improvement with rest and often with associated ingestion of contaminated food.
  • Polymyositis:  can present with persistent, symmetric proximal muscle weakness, but symptoms do not usually fluctuate, and ocular involvement is uncommon.  Patients often have mild tenderness of affected muscles.
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS):  is caused by progressive motor neuron degeneration and can cause asymmetric limb and bulbar weakness.  However, it is characterized by upper (eg, spastic paralysis) and lower (eg, muscle atrophy, fasciculations) motor neuron signs.
  • Multiple sclerosis:  can cause neurologic symptoms (eg, weakness, blurred vision) in discrete, noncontiguous domains, but symptoms typically relapse and remit slowly over days to weeks (rather than fluctuating throughout the day).
  • Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome:  is caused by inflammatory demyelination and leads to a rapidly progressive symmetric ascending muscle paralysis that can result in respiratory failure.  Symptoms are generally preceded by infection (eg, Campylobacter jejuni, viruses); hyporeflexia, dysautonomia (eg, ileus), and sensory involvement (eg, paresthesias) are common.

Management



First-line treatment of MG is typically with:



  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (eg, pyridostigmine)
  • Thymectomy


Pyridostigmine inhibits the degradation of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, prolonging the action of acetylcholine.  Because this medication increases the concentration of acetylcholine, it increases the stimulation of both nicotinic receptors, which are impacted in MG, and muscarinic receptors, which are normal in MG.  Therefore, acetylcholinesterase inhibitors improve skeletal muscle weakness but can cause muscarinic overstimulation of the smooth muscles and excessive glandular secretions (eg, diarrhea, diaphoresis, abdominal cramping, emesis).  Selective muscarinic antagonists (eg, glycopyrrolate, hyoscyamine, propantheline) can be used to reduce the adverse effects of cholinesterase inhibitors.



Patients found to have thymoma while undergoing work-up should have resection of the thymus.  However, even in the absence of thymic abnormalities, thymectomy is often beneficial in patients with MG and can lead to symptom improvement or remission.  Therefore, thymectomy is recommended in all patients age <50 who have MG, even without thymoma.



Some patients have well-controlled symptoms with first-line therapy.  However, many need additional immunotherapy to control symptoms.  Commonly used medications include corticosteroids, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, and rituximab.

Complications

Myasthenic crisis



Myasthenic crisis is a rapid, life-threatening exacerbation of muscle weakness causing respiratory failure (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  It can be precipitated by infection, surgery, or pregnancy.  In addition, certain medications, including fluoroquinolones, magnesium sulfate, and calcium channel blockers, are known to worsen symptoms and precipitate a myasthenic crisis (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Myasthenic crisis is often underrecognized due to patients' inability to recruit weakened accessory muscles (ie, no retractions or visible effort).  Patients may be approaching respiratory arrest before any overt distress is apparent.  However, increasing generalized weakness or bulbar symptoms can be warning signs.



Management includes hospital admission and close monitoring of respiratory muscle function by regularly checking FVC or negative inspiratory force.  Elective intubation should be discussed when impending respiratory failure is present.  Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine) used in the daily management of MG are held temporarily to reduce excess airway secretions and the risk for aspiration.  Patients in a myasthenic crisis are usually treated with plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin, which usually takes a few days to produce clinical improvement.

Anesthesia considerations



Patients with MG are very sensitive to agents that cause neuromuscular blockade, so the MG must be carefully managed when these are needed.



  • Nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (eg, rocuronium, vecuronium), commonly administered during intubation for surgical procedures, can unmask MG symptoms because they are competitive antagonists of nicotinic AChRs.  Because of the low number of functioning receptors, patients with MG are extremely sensitive to these agents; very small doses can induce paralysis with loss of airway patency.
  • Depolarizing agents (eg, succinylcholine) are competitive agonists of nicotinic AChRs, causing persistent depolarization with subsequent desensitization of the motor end plate.  Because of the low number of functioning receptors, patients with MG are often resistant to these agents; extremely large doses are required to induce muscle relaxation.

Prognosis



The prognosis of MG is variable and depends significantly on individual symptom severity and response to treatment.  Some patients experience long-term remission or stabilization of symptoms.  However, those with severe bulbar symptoms, late onset (age >50), or frequent exacerbations, as well as those who experience myasthenic crisis, may have a worse prognosis with long-term disability from symptoms.

Summary



Myasthenia gravis (

) is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies to AChR in the neuromuscular junction, possibly originating in the thymus.  It is characterized by fluctuating and fatigable muscle weakness and primarily affects ocular, bulbar, or proximal muscles.  Diagnosis is based on serologic tests for AChR antibodies.  Management primarily includes acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine) and thymectomy.  A common complication is a myasthenic crisis, which can cause life-threatening respiratory failure, often triggered by medications or infections.
